title: Rural Funds takes earnings hit on poultry sell-off
text:
Rural Funds Group has cut its earnings forecast for the current financial year, and taken a small property hit, after agreeing to sell its portfolio of chicken broiler sheds to First State Super-owned grower ProTen for $72 million.

The agribusiness trust, whose market value has fallen sharply after coming under fire from two overseas-based investor activist firms, cut its adjusted funds from operations (AFFO) expectations in fiscal 2020 to 13.4¢ per unit from the 14¢ forecast given at its full-year results in August.

The forecast full-year distribution for fiscal 2020 was unchanged at 10.85¢ per unit, but the payout ratio has increased to 81 per cent from 77 per cent.

The 17 broiler chicken farms sold at a 4 per cent discount to their June 30 book value of $75 million.

RFF will forego almost $11 million in rent – about 14 per cent of its annual revenue – from the sale, which requires approval by the unitholders of National Stock Exchange-listed RFM Poultry, the lessee and operator of the farms in order to terminate the lease early.

Some of this rent will be reclaimed through the $22.6 million acquisition of three WA cattle properties - Petro, High Hill and Willara. They will be leased to Wagyu beef producer Stone Axe Pastoral Company as part of a strategy to increase its weighting to natural resource-based assets over infrastructure assets.
description: The agribusiness trust will forego $11 million in annual poultry farm rental revenue, but grow its exposure to the beef cattle sector.
